article_text: One of the major issues that has been brought into the upcoming ASI election is the “parking problem." I ask the students at Cal Poly: Do we have a parking problem or an automobile problem? So far, the issue has been the creation of more parking, rather than the issue of eliminating the congestion, smog and confusion of the automobile. Every day 1 come to school (on my bicycle) and am inundated with far too many automobiles on campus. 1 have noticed that most of these cars contain only one person who, more likely than not, lives less than a rtiile away from campus. WHY? Creating more available parking would only encourage more people to use their cars. I say: I.et's not add more asphalt to our beautiful campus. Let's all work together to consolidate the number of cars on campus and eliminate the automobile problem There are many arguments for not building more parking: added cost to the university and students. depletion of land that could be put to other uses, not to mention the added traffic on campus. Fewer cars can be equated with less oil consumption. less smog, less congestion on campus, easier mobility for those using alternative transpor- tation (i.e. bicycles, walking, mopeds, buses), and people might get some exercise in the process I urge the candidates for ASI offices to take issue with the extension of parking on campus.
